rev.comment: This image use does not comply with [[WP:NFCC]] #10c and MUST be removed until it does. Thank you.
rev.diff:
Line 37: Line 37:
===Rise to fame (1994â1997)===
===Rise to fame (1994â1997)===
â
[[File:Junoon-azadi.jpg|thumb|left|200px| Junoon fourth studio album, ''[[Azadi (album)|Azadi]]'' (1997), was the band's first international record deal.]]
 
In 1994, Junoon started working on their third studio album. In 1995, the band released their first compilation album, ''[[Kashmakash]]'', which is believed to be the very first compilation album by a band in [[Pakistan]]. Junoon were courted for the controversial video release of the single "[[Ehtesaab]]", from ''Kashmakash'', which included footage of a polo pony eating in a posh restaurant. Many thought that the image was an indictment of the corrupt [[Pakistan|Pakistani]] political elite, and especially of former Prime Minister [[Benazir Bhutto]].<ref>[http://books.google.com.pk/books?id=F5_VlFyCIBgC&pg=PA149&lpg=PA149&dq=%22Ehtesaab%22+%28political+accountability%29#v=onepage&q=%22Ehtesaab%22%20%28political%20accountability%29&f=false Rock & Roll Jihad] Retrieved on July 22, 2010.</ref> The government quickly responded to it and banned the song and video from the state television.<ref name=Junoon-Biography/> In 1996, the band released their third studio album, ''[[Inquilaab]]'', which was a blend of western music with classical eastern sufi music. It was the release of their third album when Junoon started to gain success and began to reach a wider audience when one of their singles, "[[Jazba-e-Junoon]]", became the signature song of the [[1996 Cricket World Cup|Cricket World Cup]].<ref name=Junoon-Biography/>
In 1994, Junoon started working on their third studio album. In 1995, the band released their first compilation album, ''[[Kashmakash]]'', which is believed to be the very first compilation album by a band in [[Pakistan]]. Junoon were courted for the controversial video release of the single "[[Ehtesaab]]", from ''Kashmakash'', which included footage of a polo pony eating in a posh restaurant. Many thought that the image was an indictment of the corrupt [[Pakistan|Pakistani]] political elite, and especially of former Prime Minister [[Benazir Bhutto]].<ref>[http://books.google.com.pk/books?id=F5_VlFyCIBgC&pg=PA149&lpg=PA149&dq=%22Ehtesaab%22+%28political+accountability%29#v=onepage&q=%22Ehtesaab%22%20%28political%20accountability%29&f=false Rock & Roll Jihad] Retrieved on July 22, 2010.</ref> The government quickly responded to it and banned the song and video from the state television.<ref name=Junoon-Biography/> In 1996, the band released their third studio album, ''[[Inquilaab]]'', which was a blend of western music with classical eastern sufi music. It was the release of their third album when Junoon started to gain success and began to reach a wider audience when one of their singles, "[[Jazba-e-Junoon]]", became the signature song of the [[1996 Cricket World Cup|Cricket World Cup]].<ref name=Junoon-Biography/>
